A low-carbohydrate diet was noted to improve glycemic control and insulin parameters, but few studies have examined the effects of a carbohydrate-count gluten-free diet on glycemic control, growth rate, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease, particularly children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gluten induces gastrointestinal or mental health symptoms in adolescents following a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in gastrointestinal or mental health symptoms between gluten and placebo groups, suggesting gluten did not induce symptoms in this population.
population_specificity: Adolescents (median age 20.3, predominantly female) from a population-based cohort with at least four gastrointestinal symptoms.
effective_dosage: Two granola bars containing 10 g of gluten daily for 7 days.
study_duration: 2-week run-in phase (gluten-free), followed by 7-day gluten/placebo periods with a 7-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in improving symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) based on existing literature and expert opinion.
results_summary: Observational studies found that most IBS patients improve with a gluten-free diet, but randomized controlled trials have yielded mixed results, indicating inconsistent efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gluten tolerance, anxiety, and quality of life in IBS patients following a low FODMAP strict gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: Symptom scores significantly improved after 6 weeks of a low FODMAP strict GFD, with pain severity, bloating, and total scores decreasing. High-gluten groups also showed benefits, though group C (gluten-containing diet) had increased satiety scores.
population_specificity: Fifty IBS patients.
effective_dosage: 8 g/day of gluten for 2 weeks, escalating to 16 g/day and 32 g/day for gluten-tolerating subjects.
study_duration: 6 weeks initial intervention, followed by a further 6 weeks for group allocation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the clinical impact of lactose malabsorption (LM) on digestive and extra-digestive disorders, including its role in persistent symptoms in celiac disease (CD) on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that LM can contribute to persistent symptoms in CD and inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) despite a gluten-free diet, while its association with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) appears coincidental. A lactose-restricted diet may benefit some IBS patients, and LM can affect bone mass and levothyroxine absorption.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease, inflammatory bowel diseases, irritable bowel syndrome, and lactose malabsorption.
interactions: Levothyroxine absorption may be affected by lactose malabsorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a gluten-free diet could impact pain perception in women with endometriosis.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet, along with other dietary interventions, significantly reduced pain perception in women with endometriosis, though heterogeneity prevented a meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age with laparoscopically confirmed endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and critically analyze the most recent scientific guidelines on celiac disease (CD), focusing on differences in diagnostic and follow-up strategies.
results_summary: The study found relatively high concordance among guidelines for CD, with notable differences in no-biopsy diagnosis, HLA testing, and follow-up protocols. Recent modifications include the possibility of non-invasive diagnosis in children, with potential future extensions to adults.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on guidelines from scientific societies representing different geographical regions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify circulating miRNAs as non-invasive biomarkers for diagnosing Celiac Disease (CD) and monitoring adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study identified three miRNAs (miR-192-5p, miR-215-5p, and miR-125b-5p) that accurately discriminated between CD patients, GFD patients, and healthy controls, suggesting their utility for diagnosis and dietary adherence monitoring.
population_specificity: Pediatric Celiac Disease patients (both at diagnosis and on a gluten-free diet) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore bacterially mediated mechanisms contributing to celiac disease pathogenesis and potential microbial therapeutics as adjuvant therapies to the gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study highlights that the gluten-free diet, while the only current treatment for celiac disease, has limitations including high non-adherence rates and incomplete symptomatic or mucosal remission. It suggests microbial pathways may play a role in disease pathogenesis, offering potential targets for adjuvant therapies.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (genetically susceptible, immune-mediated response to gluten).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis (IPH) and celiac disease (CD) in pediatric patients and assess the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet (GFD) as initial therapy for Lane-Hamilton syndrome (LHS).
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet was associated with a positive response in 20 out of 23 pediatric patients with LHS, suggesting efficacy in managing the condition. Serology for CD was positive in all patients, and strict GFD was recommended as initial therapy.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (mean age 11 years) diagnosed with Lane-Hamilton syndrome (LHS), a rare condition combining idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis and celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential positive effects of a gluten-free diet on the course of psoriasis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that a gluten-free diet may have a positive effect on psoriasis, but it does not provide specific data or outcomes to quantify this effect. The recommendation is based on general dietary advice for psoriasis patients rather than direct study results.
population_specificity: Persons suffering from psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional challenges and dietary management of gluten-related disorders, including celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, and gluten-sensitive irritable bowel syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet (GFD) is the primary treatment for gluten-related disorders but noted that nutritional deficits can persist even on a GFD, and strict dietary therapies may negatively impact quality of life. Compliance with a GFD can be difficult, and lactose malabsorption is common in celiac disease, complicating dietary management.
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten-related disorders (celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, wheat allergy) and gluten-sensitive irritable bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and effectiveness of a lifelong, strict gluten-free diet as the only treatment for coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is the only effective treatment for coeliac disease but faces barriers like limited availability, high cost, cross-contamination, and restrictive nature, leading to adherence challenges. Variability in diagnostic methods and follow-up protocols also complicates disease management.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease (genetically susceptible individuals with immune-mediated enteropathy caused by gluten ingestion).
study_duration: Lifelong (duration not explicitly stated in the abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet in CVID patients with celiac-like disease and its appropriateness given the immune dysregulation in CVID.
results_summary: The study concluded that a gluten-free diet is not indicated for celiac-like disease in CVID, as the condition is due to immune dysregulation rather than gluten sensitivity. The abstract suggests that personalized medicine may be more appropriate for these patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) and celiac-like disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a gluten-free diet (GFD), nutritional supplements, or antiresorptive medications on bone mineral density (BMD) recovery in young adults newly diagnosed with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that newly diagnosed celiac disease patients had lower BMD compared to healthy controls, but a strict GFD may increase BMD over a follow-up period of up to 5 years. There was insufficient evidence to support the benefits of nutritional supplements or antiresorptive agents for BMD improvement in this age group.
population_specificity: Young adults (20-35 years old), primarily women, newly diagnosed with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether circulating miRNAs could predict the development of celiac disease (CeD) and assess their normalization upon starting a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study identified 53 circulating miRNAs that are potential early biomarkers for CeD, with some detectable more than a year before TGA positivity and others normalizing after GFD initiation.
population_specificity: Participants from the PreventCD study, including 33 individuals who developed CeD, with samples collected from infancy to diagnosis and post-GFD.
study_duration: Follow-up until CeD diagnosis and after GFD initiation (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet could improve ataxia in patients with anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) ataxia.
results_summary: A gluten-free diet alone improved ataxia in half of the patients with anti-GAD ataxia, suggesting gluten sensitivity might contribute to the underlying pathogenesis of this condition. The study did not provide detailed statistical analysis or effect sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) ataxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical features of non-coeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and estimate its prevalence, as well as assess the symptomatic response to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that NCGS patients were predominantly middle-aged females with symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. The prevalence of NCGS after double-blind, placebo-controlled trials was 24%, and symptomatic response to GFD varied widely (7%-93%). Long-term benefits of GFD remain unclear.
population_specificity: Middle-aged females with non-coeliac gluten sensitivity, including those with irritable bowel syndrome or self-reported gluten intolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of gluten-free diet among other dietary interventions in modifying disease severity and patient-reported outcomes in multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-free diet did not demonstrate a positive effect on MS course or patient-reported outcomes, unlike low-carbohydrate, Mediterranean, and fast-mimicking diets.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiology, diagnosis, and treatment of celiac disease, emphasizing the role of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment.
results_summary: The study confirms that a strict gluten-free diet remains the mainstay of treatment for celiac disease, effectively managing symptoms and complications. Novel therapies are being developed, but the diet's efficacy is well-established.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the indications, proven benefits, and adverse events of a gluten-free diet (GFD) and assess its effectiveness in managing mental and cognitive disorders.
results_summary: The study found that while GFD is effective for gluten-induced immune-mediated disorders, it carries disadvantages such as elevated costs, nutritional deficiencies, and social and psychological barriers. More data is needed to evaluate its effectiveness for mental and cognitive disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with gluten-induced immune-mediated disorders (e.g., celiac disease, dermatitis herpetiformis, gluten ataxia, wheat allergy, non-celiac gluten sensitivity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an evidence-based approach for diagnosing and managing seronegative villous atrophy (SNVA), including cases where a gluten-free diet might be unnecessary.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges in diagnosing SNVA and the risks of misdiagnosis, which can lead to unnecessary lifelong gluten-free diets or incorrect immunosuppressive therapy. It emphasizes the need for a practical diagnostic approach but does not report specific outcomes related to gluten-free diet efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with seronegative villous atrophy (SNVA), including potential cases of seronegative coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in treating celiac disease and explore alternative therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is less effective than previously believed, with patients remaining vulnerable to gluten-induced symptoms and systemic cytokine release. It also highlighted the need for pharmacological adjuncts and better diagnostic tools.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the risk of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in celiac disease patients adhering to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The systematic review found that GFD in celiac disease patients may increase the risk of NAFLD due to consumption of products rich in saturated fats and carbohydrates, leading to hepatic steatosis and inflammation. Eight studies supported this association over follow-up periods ranging from six months to a median of 10 years.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients adhering to a gluten-free diet.
study_duration: Six months to a median of 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a pragmatic guide on the investigation and clinical management of seronegative enteropathies, focusing on the role of a gluten-free diet in diagnosing seronegative coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is effective in confirming the diagnosis of seronegative coeliac disease through clinical and histological response, after excluding other causes of villous atrophy. It highlighted the importance of correct identification and targeted management due to varying clinical outcomes and prognoses.
population_specificity: Adults with seronegative enteropathies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical utility of gluten immunogenic peptides (GIP) determination in monitoring adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) compared to other tools.
results_summary: The study found that GIP determination in stool and urine was highly sensitive for detecting GFD transgressions, with adherence rates varying between 30%-93%. Other methods like serology, dietetic questionnaires, and symptomatology showed varying adherence rates and associations with histological abnormalities.
population_specificity: Children and adults diagnosed with celiac disease (CeD) and healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet in managing celiac disease and its associated autoimmune conditions.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is the most effective treatment for celiac disease, though about 20% of patients remain symptomatic due to noncompliance or poor dietary understanding. Non-dietary therapies are under investigation but remain in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease, including children and adults, particularly those with associated autoimmune conditions.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of iron deficiency and related nutritional deficiencies in celiac disease patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that iron deficiency anemia is common in celiac disease patients, potentially affecting over half at diagnosis, and mentions other contributing factors like folate and vitamin B12 malabsorption.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current scientific evidence on skin manifestations associated with celiac disease (CD) in pediatric populations and the therapeutic role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in improving these manifestations.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is crucial for improving cutaneous manifestations in adults with CD, particularly dermatitis herpetiformis, but its therapeutic role in children and other dermatological conditions like psoriasis and atopic dermatitis remains less understood. Early diagnosis and GFD adherence are critical for better prognosis in CD patients with skin symptoms.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations with celiac disease, focusing on those with cutaneous manifestations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms of gluten-induced intestinal remodeling in celiac disease (CeD) and discuss findings from tissue "omics" studies related to disease pathogenesis.
results_summary: The study highlights that a gluten-free diet is the only current treatment for CeD, effectively managing symptoms like nausea and diarrhea by preventing gluten-induced inflammation and intestinal remodeling. It also emphasizes the need for further understanding of the mechanisms driving intestinal remodeling in CeD.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (genetically susceptible individuals mounting a harmful CD4+ T-cell response to gluten peptides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of elevated transaminases in newly diagnosed pediatric celiac patients and assess the clinical course following a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Elevated ALT was present in 25% of newly diagnosed pediatric celiac patients, with most normalizing within 3 months on a gluten-free diet. The clinical course, growth, and serology normalization were similar between patients with elevated and normal ALT.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed pediatric celiac patients (mean age 5.5–7.3 years).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of a gluten-free diet (GFD) for pain management in women with chronic myofascial pain in masticatory muscles.
results_summary: Participants on a GFD showed reduced pain intensity and increased pressure pain thresholds in masseter and anterior temporalis muscles, while the control group showed no improvement. The intervention did not affect mechanical pain thresholds.
population_specificity: 39 female subjects with chronic myofascial pain in masticatory muscles, divided into healthy, control, and experimental groups.
effective_dosage: Individualized GFD prescribed by a nutritionist (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gaps in the diagnosis and management of coeliac disease and prioritize high-yield research areas, including the effectiveness of the gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that the gluten-free diet, while the only available management for coeliac disease, is not curative or universally effective, with some patients experiencing ongoing duodenal injury despite adherence. Emerging therapies with novel mechanisms are being investigated to address these limitations.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease, including genetically predisposed individuals and those with ongoing symptoms despite adherence to a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of confocal laser endomicroscopy (CLE) for identifying wheat sensitivity (WS) in non-celiac IBS patients and assess the response to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that 56.9% of IBS patients responded to a GFD, classifying them as wheat-sensitive. CLE showed moderate sensitivity (51.4%) and specificity (67.9%) for identifying WS initially, with improved sensitivity (83.1%) but reduced specificity (32%) at 6-month follow-up. The authors concluded CLE's diagnostic accuracy was insufficient for widespread use.
population_specificity: Non-celiac patients meeting Rome III criteria for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
study_duration: 2 months (initial GFD intervention), with follow-ups at 6 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotics on immunological response and fecal microbiota in children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics combined with a gluten-free diet helped restore fecal microbiota to conditions resembling healthy individuals and reduced proinflammatory cytokines like TNF-alpha. However, the need for larger, multicentric studies with longer follow-up was emphasized.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (1-19 years) with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.
effective_dosage: Strains of Bifidobacterium breve or B. longum (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current diagnostic methods, disease monitoring, and management options (including gluten-free diet) for dermatitis herpetiformis (DH).
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet (GFD) is a mainstay of treatment for DH, often combined with dapsone, and well-controlled DH patients have an excellent prognosis when managed by a multidisciplinary team.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) caused by gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical phenotypes and long-term outcomes of seronegative coeliac disease versus seropositive coeliac disease, focusing on the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing symptoms and complications.
results_summary: The study found that seronegative coeliac disease had more severe symptoms and higher risks of complications and mortality compared to seropositive coeliac disease, but both groups responded to a GFD. True seronegative coeliac disease and coeliac disease with IgA deficiency showed similar outcomes, with age, lack of clinical response to GFD, and disease type predicting complications and mortality.
population_specificity: Patients with seronegative coeliac disease (HLA-DQ2/DQ8-positive with villous atrophy and negative serology) and seropositive coeliac disease controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connection between idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIM) and celiac disease (CeD) and assess the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on IIM symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that in 58% of cases, IIM symptoms improved after starting a GFD, with 29% achieving remission using GFD alone. Some patients showed improvement even without classical CeD symptoms or positive serology.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIM) and concomitant small intestinal biopsy findings consistent with celiac disease (CeD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical research and clinical trials on pharmacological approaches (AT-1001 and IMGX-003) for treating Celiac Disease (CeD) and compare them to the gluten-free diet as the current standard treatment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that a gluten-free diet is the only recommended treatment to alleviate CeD symptoms, as no FDA-approved medications exist. Two advanced clinical trials (AT-1001 and IMGX-003) are exploring alternative pharmacological treatments with different mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Individuals with Celiac Disease (CeD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional imbalances in adults with celiac disease following a gluten-free diet (GFD) and assess its effectiveness in managing the condition.
results_summary: The study found that while a GFD helps recover intestinal mucosa and alleviate symptoms in the short term, long-term adherence may lead to nutritional deficiencies, including low complex carbohydrates and fiber, high fat and sugar intake, and deficiencies in iron, calcium, magnesium, and certain vitamins. Nutritional education is recommended to achieve a balanced diet.
population_specificity: Adults with celiac disease
study_duration: First year of treatment and long-term follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pathogenesis of celiac disease (CeD) and evaluate the limitations of a lifelong gluten-free diet, while highlighting novel therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The study found that while a gluten-free diet is the primary treatment for CeD, it often does not lead to complete mucosal healing and poses a burden to patients. Recent research suggests multiple cofactors and genetic predispositions, paving the way for alternative therapies such as gluten-degrading enzymes, TG2 inhibition, and cytokine therapies.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (CeD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess current evidence on initiatives addressing gluten content in medicines and raising awareness among healthcare professionals about prescribing and dispensing gluten-containing medicines to patients with celiac disease and other gluten-related disorders.
results_summary: The review identified 13 relevant studies, mostly from the US, focusing on increasing healthcare professionals' knowledge about gluten-free medications, with variability in information and labeling practices across countries. Initiatives are evolving but remain limited in scope and effectiveness for practical use.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease and other gluten-related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of Epstein-Barr virus-positive intestinal diffuse large B-cell lymphoma complicating celiac disease in a patient on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that while the gluten-free diet initially managed celiac disease effectively for five years, the patient later developed a rare lymphoma, suggesting a potential complication despite dietary adherence.
population_specificity: A 60-year-old Japanese woman with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a gluten-free diet (GFD) as a therapeutic strategy for classical non-gluten-dependent autoimmune diseases.
results_summary: The study found that 64.7% of patients (911 out of 1408) experienced a reduction in autoimmune disease symptoms after following a GFD, with 79.5% of the included studies (66 out of 83) reporting positive outcomes. The GFD was suggested to suppress harmful intestinal events and potentially act through gut-remote organ pathways.
population_specificity: Patients aged 9 months to 69 years with various autoimmune diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of larazotide acetate (AT-1001) as a treatment for celiac disease, comparing its effects in patients undergoing gluten challenge versus those on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: AT-1001 showed significant symptomatic improvement in gastrointestinal symptoms for celiac disease patients undergoing gluten challenge but no significant difference for those on a gluten-free diet. It also reduced gluten-related diarrhea in the gluten challenge group, with other adverse events comparable to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (n=626, with 465 receiving AT-1001 and 161 placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a low FODMAP-gluten free diet (LF-GFD) on clinical symptoms, gut microbiota diversity, and fecal calprotectin levels in Iranian patients with IBS.
results_summary: The study found that LF-GFD significantly reduced IBS symptom severity, altered gut microbiota composition (increased Bacteroidetes and decreased Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio), and lowered fecal calprotectin levels.
population_specificity: Iranian patients with IBS (Rome IV criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in celiac disease patients and assess the impact of celiac disease on the risk of contracting the virus.
results_summary: The study found that the incidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in celiac patients was not significantly different from the general population, though the positive/diagnostic swabs ratio appeared higher, possibly due to fewer patients being tested.
population_specificity: 542 celiac disease patients
study_duration: Retrospective data from 20th January 2020 to 27th October 2020

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and risks associated with maintaining a strict gluten-free diet for individuals with celiac disease, including gluten contamination in foods and other products.
results_summary: The study found that maintaining a strict gluten-free diet is difficult, with significant risks of gluten contamination in both natural and certified gluten-free foods, as well as in meals from food services. Improper labeling, incorrect gluten quantitation, and poor consumer awareness contribute to inadvertent gluten intake.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily gluten intake should not exceed 10 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate non-dietary alternatives to the gluten-free diet (GFD) for celiac disease (CD) due to its limitations and frequent dietary transgressions.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for non-dietary therapies for CD, reviewing various approaches like gluten degradation, immune response regulation, and intestinal permeability modulation, with promising results from phase II and III clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the degree of adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD), the methods to assess it, and the barriers to its implementation in patients with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that monitoring adherence to a GFD is challenging, with current methods (dietary questionnaires, serology, clinical symptoms) lacking direct accuracy. Cross-contamination and limited availability of gluten-free products contribute to non-adherence, leading to persistent gluten consumption and intestinal damage in many patients.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: To determine whether concurrent budesonide and gluten-free diet hasten small bowel healing and symptomatic improvement in patients with newly diagnosed coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in mucosal healing or clinical measures between budesonide and placebo groups when combined with a gluten-free diet. Mucosal remission at 8 weeks occurred in approximately one in four patients and was associated with less severe histological lesions at diagnosis.
population_specificity: Patients with newly diagnosed coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) in coeliac patients and evaluate factors influencing this adherence.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to GFD was generally good (92.5% by GIP, 86.3% by dietary test), but identified challenges such as difficulty in following the diet, variability in eating sites, lack of variety, and increased cost of gluten-free foods. Age and time of onset were significantly associated with adherence.
population_specificity: 80 coeliac patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an up-to-date overview of non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), including its epidemiology, pathogenesis, and current dietary interventions like the gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that NCGS diagnosis relies on placebo-controlled gluten challenges, but the effectiveness of gluten-free and low-FODMAP diets remains controversial. More research is needed to understand NCGS triggers and immune interactions.
population_specificity: Patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), excluding those with celiac disease or wheat allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze whether there is a pathophysiological relationship between dietary intake of gluten or FODMAPs and mental disorders.
results_summary: The review found that limiting or excluding gluten or FODMAPs might benefit symptoms of depression, anxiety, and cognition deficiency, with some positive effects on schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorders. However, further studies are needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Individuals with mental disorders (depression, anxiety, cognition deficiency, schizophrenia, autism spectrum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review psychosocial factors associated with quality of life in adults with coeliac disease following a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that symptoms of depression and anxiety, psychological distress, illness perceptions, coping strategies, and attitudes/behaviors regarding food and the gluten-free diet were differentially associated with quality of life in adults with coeliac disease. These factors may influence quality of life directly via reduced psychological well-being and indirectly via reduced adherence to the diet.
population_specificity: Adults with coeliac disease (80.2% female, mean age = 46.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing iron deficiency anemia (IDA) in patients with celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found that a GFD is associated with adequate management of IDA in CD patients, though normalization of iron stores can take 6 months to 2 years. Oral iron replacement with ferrous sulphate (FS) has limited absorption in active CD and unpredictable absorption even on a GFD, with poor tolerability frequently reported.
population_specificity: Patients with newly diagnosed celiac disease (CD) and iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of a gluten-free diet in preventing enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma (EATL) in patients with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of adherence to a gluten-free diet for preventing EATL in celiac disease patients, emphasizing early diagnosis and surveillance for pre-lymphoma lesions.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, particularly those at risk for EATL (e.g., HLA-DQ2 homozygotes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of TNFα and IL-17A producing T cells in dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) and assess the impact of a gluten-free diet on circulating T lymphocytes' phenotype and antigen-specific responses.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet reduced circulating T cells producing TNFα and IL-17A, which correlated with decreased skin disease activity. It also identified cross-reactive T cell responses to epidermal and tissue transglutaminases in DH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) and coeliac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in managing celiac disease and discuss the need for improved biomarkers to monitor therapeutic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet effectively controls symptoms and intestinal damage for many celiac disease patients, though some patients experience disease progression despite dietary adherence. The abstract highlights the need for better biomarkers to assess therapeutic activity and durability.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gluten in triggering immune-related diseases and evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment option.
results_summary: The study found that gluten triggers immune responses leading to celiac disease, wheat allergy, and non-celiac gluten sensitivity, with a gluten-free diet being the only efficient treatment. Alternative approaches, such as gluten-degrading enzymes or environmental bacteria, were suggested but require further investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of gluten-related conditions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic challenges and multidisciplinary management of celiac disease, emphasizing the importance of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in treatment.
results_summary: The study underscores the necessity of a gluten-free diet for managing celiac disease, noting its critical role in patient care and the importance of collaboration among healthcare providers to ensure compliance and avoid gluten exposure in medications.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, including children and adults, with varying symptom presentations (classic, asymptomatic, or extra-intestinal forms).
interactions: Gluten-containing medications were noted as a potential interaction, requiring careful prescription and dispensing by healthcare providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of a gluten-free diet for patients with potential celiac disease (PCD) and determine its role in preventing progression to full celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found that patients with clinical gastroenterological or parenteral symptoms often benefit from a gluten-free diet, while those remaining on a gluten-containing diet require close monitoring. The abstract suggests individualized therapeutic decisions due to the heterogeneous nature of PCD.
population_specificity: Patients with potential celiac disease (PCD), particularly those with clinical gastroenterological or parenteral symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current understanding and clinical management of celiac disease, focusing on the limitations and burdens of the gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that the GFD is an imperfect treatment for celiac disease, with not all individuals responding to it. Additionally, the diet is burdensome and difficult to achieve, leading to incomplete efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease and those without celiac disease using a GFD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between Ménière's disease and dietary interventions, including a gluten-free diet, for preventing and treating attacks.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that dietary modifications, including a gluten-free diet, are considered first-line treatments for Ménière's disease, but no specific results regarding the gluten-free diet's effectiveness are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with Ménière's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety, tolerability, and gluten-degrading efficacy of TAK-062, a novel endopeptidase, in healthy participants and patients with celiac disease.
results_summary: TAK-062 degraded more than 99% of gluten in vitro within 10 minutes and achieved 97% to over 99% degradation in complex meals in healthy participants. The enzyme was well tolerated and showed rapid, effective gluten degradation.
population_specificity: Healthy participants and patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of intestinal epithelial cell disturbances caused by gluten intake in coeliac disease and the role of a gluten-free diet in treatment.
results_summary: The study found that gluten intake disrupts intestinal epithelial cells, leading to dysfunction, crypt hyperplasia, and increased permeability, which exacerbates immune responses. A gluten-free diet is essential for treating coeliac disease, but additional therapies targeting epithelial healing are under development.
population_specificity: Coeliac disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of tight junction disruption in coeliac disease and assess whether a gluten-free diet fully restores intestinal barrier function.
results_summary: The study found that tight junction structures and function remain disrupted in coeliac disease even after treatment with a gluten-free diet, and zonulin levels are elevated in autoimmune conditions like coeliac disease.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet in treating celiac disease and preventing its complications, while also assessing potential risks like metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is effective for treating celiac disease but may increase the risk of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and adverse effects on glucose and lipid metabolism if not properly balanced. Nutritional counseling was recommended to mitigate these risks.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with celiac disease.
